fact_text: Consuming plant-based iron (like spinach) with Vitamin C (like lemon or bell peppers) significantly increases iron absorption.
Vitamin D is essential for absorbing calcium; without it, your body cannot effectively build bone mass.
Magnesium plays a key role in muscle relaxation and can help prevent cramps and fatigue.
Adequate potassium intake (found in bananas and potatoes) helps counteract the negative effects of sodium on blood pressure.
Zinc is crucial for the development and function of immune cells and helps heal wounds.
Heme iron found in meat is absorbed more efficiently by the body than non-heme iron found in plants.
While sodium is necessary for fluid balance, excessive intake is linked to high blood pressure and heart strain.
Brazil nuts are one of the richest dietary sources of selenium, a powerful antioxidant mineral.
Phosphorus works with calcium to build strong bones and teeth and is needed for tissue repair.
Iodine is vital for thyroid health, which regulates your metabolism.
Copper helps your body make red blood cells and keeps nerve cells and your immune system healthy.
Sodium, potassium, and magnesium are electrolytes that help regulate nerve and muscle function and hydration.
Tannins found in tea and coffee can inhibit the absorption of iron if consumed during meals.
Magnesium supplements or magnesium-rich foods can improve sleep quality by regulating neurotransmitters.
Protein has the highest thermic effect of food, meaning your body burns more calories digesting it than fats or carbs.
There are 9 amino acids your body cannot produce; you must get them from food sources.
Animal proteins are 'complete' (containing all 9 essential amino acids), while most plant proteins are 'incomplete' and need variety.
Consuming protein shortly after a workout helps repair muscle tissue and stimulate growth.
Quinoa is one of the few plant foods that is a complete protein, containing all essential amino acids.
Soy is one of the few plant proteins that contain all essential amino acids in good amounts.
Spreading protein intake across meals is more effective for muscle building than eating it all at once.
Vitamins A, D, E, and K require dietary fat to be absorbed by the body.
Omega-3 fatty acids, found in fatty fish, are crucial for brain health and reducing inflammation.
Trans fats raise your 'bad' cholesterol (LDL) and lower your 'good' cholesterol (HDL), increasing heart disease risk.
Monounsaturated fats found in olive oil and avocados can improve heart health and help regulate blood sugar.
Your body cannot make Omega-3 and Omega-6 fatty acids; they must come from your diet.
For most people, dietary cholesterol (like in eggs) has a minimal effect on blood cholesterol levels compared to saturated fat.
Avocados are not only rich in healthy fats but are also surprisingly high in fiber.
Complex carbs (oats, brown rice) provide sustained energy, while simple carbs (sugar) cause rapid spikes and crashes.
Soluble fiber (oats, apples) helps lower cholesterol; insoluble fiber (wheat bran) aids digestion and prevents constipation.
Your brain consumes about 20% of your daily energy, primarily in the form of glucose (carbohydrates).
For every gram of carbohydrate stored in the body (as glycogen), the body stores about 3 to 4 grams of water.
The Glycemic Index measures how quickly food raises blood sugar; low GI foods provide more stable energy.
Most adults need 25-30g of fiber daily, but the average intake is only about 15g.
Vitamin B12 is naturally found almost exclusively in animal products; vegans often need supplements.
Vitamin A helps form rhodopsin, a pigment in the eye that helps you see in low light.
Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting; without it, even small cuts could bleed excessively.
Vitamin E acts as an antioxidant, protecting cells from damage caused by free radicals.
Vitamin D is unique because your body can produce it when your skin is exposed to sunlight.
Folate is the natural form of Vitamin B9 found in foods; folic acid is the synthetic form used in supplements.
Vitamin C is sensitive to heat; cooking vegetables for too long can destroy a significant amount of it.
B-vitamins don't provide energy themselves, but they help convert the food you eat into usable energy.
The body converts beta-carotene (found in orange vegetables like carrots) into Vitamin A as needed.
Vitamins C and E work better together than alone in protecting cells from oxidative stress.
Riboflavin (B2) is crucial for breaking down proteins, fats, and carbohydrates and is vital for the body's energy supply.
Niacin (B3) helps keep your nervous system, digestive system, and skin healthy.
Choline is essential for liver function, normal brain development, and muscle movement.
The body cannot store Vitamin C, so you need to consume it regularly through your diet.
Even mild dehydration (1-2% loss of body fluid) can impair cognitive function and concentration.
About 20% of your daily water intake typically comes from the food you eat, especially fruits and vegetables.
By the time you feel thirsty, you are likely already slightly dehydrated.
Chia seeds can absorb up to 10-12 times their weight in water, helping with hydration and fullness.
Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) is the number of calories your body burns at rest just to keep vital organs functioning.
Digestion itself burns calories; protein burns the most, followed by carbs, then fats.
Muscle tissue burns more calories at rest than fat tissue, boosting your metabolism.
Eating frequent small meals vs. fewer large meals has a negligible effect on overall metabolism (total calories matter more).
Metabolism naturally slows down with age, primarily due to a loss of muscle mass.
A 500 calorie daily deficit typically leads to about 0.5kg (1lb) weight loss per week.
Spinach is high in calcium, but also high in oxalates, which can block calcium absorption.
Cooked tomatoes contain higher levels of absorbable lycopene (a powerful antioxidant) than raw tomatoes.
The egg yolk contains most of the egg's vitamins and minerals, while the white is mostly protein.
Crushing or chopping garlic and letting it sit for a few minutes before cooking activates its beneficial compounds.
Dark berries (blueberries, blackberries) are among the highest antioxidant foods available.
Leafy greens like kale and spinach are among the most nutrient-dense foods per calorie.
Smaller fish (like sardines) typically contain less mercury than larger predatory fish (like swordfish).
Beans and lentils are excellent sources of both fiber and protein, making them highly satiating.
Dark chocolate (70% cocoa or higher) is rich in minerals like iron and magnesium and contains antioxidants.
Greek yogurt typically has double the protein and half the sugar of regular yogurt.
Broccoli, cauliflower, and Brussels sprouts contain compounds linked to lower cancer risk.
Cinnamon has been shown to help lower blood sugar levels and improve insulin sensitivity.
Frozen vegetables are often flash-frozen at peak ripeness and can be just as nutritious as fresh ones.
Nitrates found in beets and leafy greens can improve blood flow and exercise performance.
Polyphenols found in tea, coffee, and berries are plant compounds that boost digestion and brain health.
Curcumin, the active compound in turmeric, has powerful anti-inflammatory effects (enhanced by black pepper).
Eating slowly allows your brain time to receive the 'fullness' signal from your stomach, preventing overeating.
Your gut contains trillions of bacteria that influence everything from digestion to mood and immunity.
Probiotics are live beneficial bacteria found in fermented foods like yogurt, kefir, and sauerkraut.
Prebiotics are types of fiber (like in garlic and onions) that feed the healthy bacteria in your gut.
Ultra-processed foods often lack fiber and nutrients while being calorie-dense, leading to easy overconsumption.
Ingredients on a nutrition label are listed in descending order by weight.
Sugar appears under many names on labels, including high fructose corn syrup, dextrose, and cane juice.
Foods high in sugar and fat but low in nutrients supply 'empty calories' that provide energy without nourishment.
Eating a variety of colorful vegetables ensures you get a diverse range of vitamins and phytonutrients.
Thoroughly chewing food is the first step of digestion and helps your body absorb more nutrients.
Sugary drinks don't trigger fullness signals the same way solid food does, leading to excess calorie intake.
Chronic stress can negatively impact digestion and nutrient absorption.
Plate sizes have grown over the decades, leading to larger portion sizes and increased calorie intake.
Cravings are often psychological or due to blood sugar crashes rather than actual nutrient deficiencies.
Tryptophan, an amino acid found in turkey and milk, is a precursor to serotonin, which regulates sleep.
Not all nutrients in food are absorbed; cooking methods and food combinations affect bioavailability.
Capsaicin, the compound that makes chili peppers spicy, can slightly boost metabolism and reduce appetite.
Insulin is the hormone that acts as a key to let glucose into cells to be used for energy.
The recommended daily sodium limit is 2,300mg - about 1 teaspoon of salt.
Planning meals ahead reduces the likelihood of making unhealthy food choices.
Consistency in diet and nutrition matters far more than occasional 'perfect' or 'cheat' meals.
Vitamin C supports your immune system and helps your body heal wounds faster.
Vitamin D helps your body absorb calcium, which is essential for strong bones and teeth.
Folate (Vitamin B9) is especially important during pregnancy for proper development of the baby's brain and spine.
Iron carries oxygen in your blood to all parts of your body; low iron causes fatigue and weakness.
Calcium is the most abundant mineral in your body and is essential for bone health, muscle function, and nerve signaling.
Salmon is one of the best sources of Omega-3 fatty acids, which support heart and brain health.
Bell peppers contain more Vitamin C than oranges, ounce for ounce.
Whole fruits are healthier than fruit juice because they contain fiber that slows sugar absorption.
Fiber helps you feel full longer, aids digestion, and can help maintain healthy cholesterol levels.
